user_message:
<misra_rule>
MISRA C 2023 Rule 2.1 is: A project shall not contain unreachable code.

</misra_rule>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- is_rule_violated: whether the rule is violated or not (true/false),
- scenario: a specific violation scenario.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of new_connections_list_process_:
```c
static void
new_connections_list_process_ (struct MHD_Daemon *daemon)
{
  struct MHD_Connection *local_head;
  struct MHD_Connection *local_tail;
  mhd_assert (daemon->have_new);
  mhd_assert (MHD_D_IS_THREAD_SAFE_ (daemon));

  /* Detach DL-list of new connections from the daemon for
   * following local processing. */
  MHD_mutex_lock_chk_ (&daemon->new_connections_mutex);
  mhd_assert (NULL != daemon->new_connections_head);
  local_head = daemon->new_connections_head;
  local_tail = daemon->new_connections_tail;
  daemon->new_connections_head = NULL;
  daemon->new_connections_tail = NULL;
  daemon->have_new = false;
  MHD_mutex_unlock_chk_ (&daemon->new_connections_mutex);
  (void) local_head; /* Mute compiler warning */

  /* Process new connections in FIFO order. */
  do
  {
    struct MHD_Connection *c;   /**< Currently processed connection */

    c = local_tail;
    DLL_remove (local_head,
                local_tail,
                c);
    mhd_assert (daemon == c->daemon);
    if (MHD_NO == new_connection_process_ (daemon, c))
    {
#ifdef HAVE_MESSAGES
      MHD_DLOG (daemon,
                _ ("Failed to start serving new connection.\n"));
#endif
      (void) 0;
    }
  } while (NULL != local_tail);

}
```
</target_code>
<target_code>
Here is the code fragment that you need to analyze:
```c
  (void) local_head; /* Mute compiler warning */

  /* Process new connections in FIFO order. */
  do
  {
    struct MHD_Connection *c;   /**< Currently processed connection */

    c = local_tail;
    DLL_remove (local_head,
                local_tail,
                c);
    mhd_assert (daemon == c->daemon);
    if (MHD_NO == new_connection_process_ (daemon, c))
    {
#ifdef HAVE_MESSAGES
      MHD_DLOG (daemon,
                _ ("Failed to start serving new connection.\n"));
#endif
      (void) 0;
    }
  } while (NULL != local_tail);
```
Focus on the above code fragment and judge whether it violates the rule 2.1 or not.
</target_code>
scenario: No violation. All statements in the fragment are reachable: the preceding code asserts and detaches a non-NULL list head/tail, so the do { … } while (NULL != local_tail); loop will execute at least once and terminate when local_tail becomes NULL (set by DLL_remove). The if branch and its inner (void)0 are reachable when new_connection_process_() returns MHD_NO; the conditional logging is controlled by HAVE_MESSAGES but, if absent, the (void)0 empty statement remains reachable. There is no unreachable code in this fragment.
